comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content:
NYTimes reported in 1913:
"HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 22. -- The townsfolk here are waiting with much curiosity for the suffrage pageant which Gen. Rosalie Jones has arranged for next Saturday afternoon. On that day those interested in the suffrage cause, will march from Mineola to this place. At the trolley junction the parade will be reviewed by Assemblyman O'Keefe and officials of Nassau County."
Flower girls in the springtime would make sense, too. Two days later, also in the New York Times:
"Hempstead, N.Y., May 24. -- Three miles of public highway between Mineola and Hempstead were crowded this afternoon with a long line of automobiles from all parts of Nassau County as they followed the suffrage pageant, in which 500 women and a few men marched as enthusiastic upholders of the cause."

comment._content: We've come a long way, baby.  I don't understand why it took so long for the lunk heads in Washington to realize that women are HUMAN BEINGS.  Women worked hard for a nickel an hour or less.  They carried and delivered the babies who became famous men.  Just how STUPID were we?

comment._content: @ budderflyman -- while I agree with the sentiment of your comment ;-) it's important to remember that passing (ratifying) an Amendment to the Constitution is the job of the (several) States -- not "Washington". Many of the most vocal activists against suffrage were women.

comment.author: 34559136@N03
comment._content: Greetings! I am currently writing an article on the 1913 suffragette pageant that occurred here on Long Island. The woman in the center (third from left) was identified in period newspapers as Marjorie Cullen. The woman on the far left was identified as Susanne Byman. The woman who is second from far right was identified as Rose Roth. If you find any images of a horse drawing a wagon associated with the Rosalie Jones suffrage march on Washington DC, the horse may be the famed "Lausanne" ('the bargain horse") - so named because "he was purchased for $59.98, reduced from $60" to pull the Suffrage Army's yellow wagon on the march to Washington. Lausanne became an part of the news coverage during the trek (he apparently did not participate in the Long Island pageant, as he had passed away by then). - Daniel E Russell Former City Historian Glen Cove, Long Island -- Found in a search. (?)
